FunctionInvocationExpressionStatement() FunctionInvocationExpressionStatementLuthetus.CompilerServices.CSharp.Tests.SmokeTests.Parsers.ExpressionTests Luthetus.CompilerServices.CSharp.Tests.SmokeTests.Parsers.ExpressionTestsFunctionInvocationExpressionStatement
void Luthetus.CompilerServices.CSharp.Tests.SmokeTests.Parsers.ExpressionTests.FunctionInvocationExpressionStatement ( )
This parses incorrectly: 'Func(decimalPercentProgress);'.
Whereas this parses fine: 'var x = Func(decimalPercentProgress);'
The reason is suspected to be the transition from the 'statement' parser loop to the 'expression' parser loop.
It actually seems to be related to 'int decimalPercentProgress;', i.e.: declaring the variable results in it erroneously being interpreted as a TypeClauseNode, yet if it is undeclared then it comes out to be VariableReferenceNode.
